description: The Doomsday Clock is introduced, set at 7 minutes to midnight, symbolizing the looming threat of nuclear war.
The Soviet Union tests its first atomic bomb, escalating the nuclear arms race.
Both the U.S. and the Soviet Union test thermonuclear devices within months, intensifying global tensions.
Global awareness of nuclear risks grows, leading to initial disarmament talks.
The Partial Test Ban Treaty is signed, prohibiting atmospheric nuclear tests.
France and China develop nuclear weapons; proliferation concerns increase.
The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty comes into effect, aiming to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
The U.S. and the Soviet Union sign the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty (SALT I).
India conducts its first nuclear test; superpower relations become strained.
The Soviet invasion of Afghanistan heightens Cold War tensions.
Escalation of the arms race with the deployment of new U.S. and Soviet missiles.
Communication between superpowers breaks down; nuclear war fears increase.
The U.S. and Soviet Union sign the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty.
The Cold War begins to end with the fall of the Berlin Wall and improved U.S.-Soviet relations.
The dissolution of the Soviet Union reduces the nuclear threat significantly.
Concerns over nuclear proliferation rise due to stalled disarmament efforts.
India and Pakistan conduct nuclear tests, increasing regional tensions.
Withdrawal from arms control treaties and the threat of terrorism raise nuclear risks.
Climate change is added as a significant global threat alongside nuclear proliferation.
Global efforts to reduce nuclear arsenals and address climate change show progress.
Insufficient action on nuclear disarmament and climate change leads to increased risk.
Failure to address climate change and modernization of nuclear weapons heighten dangers.
Rising nationalism and nuclear rhetoric contribute to global instability.
The Bulletin sets the clock the closest to midnight since 1953 due to multiple threats.
Nuclear risks and inaction on climate change keep the clock at 2 minutes to midnight.
The clock moves closer, reflecting increased nuclear risks and inadequate climate action.
Pandemic, disinformation, and lack of progress on global threats maintain the time.
Ongoing threats including COVID-19 and climate change keep the clock at its closest point.
The clock is set at 90 seconds to midnight, the closest ever, citing the war in Ukraine and escalating global tensions.
